abstracts.cdata!:
The First Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project had the following ratings: outcome was moderately
            satisfactory; sustainability was likely; institutional
            development impact was modest; Bank performance was
            satisfactory; and borrower performance was satisfactory. The
            Economic Recovery Credit Project had the following ratings:
            outcome was highly satisfactory; sustainability was likely;
            institutional development impact was not evaluable; Bank
            performance was unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was
            satisfactory. The Economic Management Credit Project had the
            following ratings: outcome was moderately satisfactory;
            sustainability was likely; institutional development impact
            was modest; Bank performance was unsatisfactory; and
            borrower performance was satisfactory. The Third Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project had the following ratings: outcome
            was moderately unsatisfactory; sustainability was likely;
            institutional development impact was modest; Bank
            performance was unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was
            satisfactory. The main lessons learned from this review are:
            1) Country ownership matters very much. The components of
            the loans that were owned by the country, such as the public
            resource management and some of the structural adjustment
            components were generally successfully implemented; 2) As a
            general rule, it would be very useful for the Bank to listen
            better and to go to extra lengths to explain it s positions,
            and to solicit views and seek genuine agreement with country
            authorities. This could improve country ownership of
            programs; 3) It is important to keep a good and substantive
            dialogue with the main development partners; again by
            listening better to their view points, keeping them better
            informed about those of the Bank, and seeking to reach
            agreements when possible; and 4) As has happened already
            with the Fourth Structural Adjustment Credit, it would be
            preferable to keep the design of adjustment operations
            simple and focused on a limited number of key policy areas,
            whose implementation can be realistically expected within
            the short disbursement period dictated by an adjustment operation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall achievement of the program
            objectives is rated as substantial. The main reason for
            success was the strong ownership of reform agenda and
            sustained commitment by the Malian Government to strengthen
            its policy reforms and its open dialogue with the Bank. The
            following factors, subject to Government control, positively
            affected the program implementation: (i) strong commitment
            of the Government and its open dialogue with the Bank-; (ii)
            the Government's clear vision of the objectives of the
            economic reform program and its willingness to adopt the
            appropriate means to achieve the objectives; (iii) an
            effective mass media campaign to inform and educate the
            public about the merits and consequences of the devaluation
            and the accompanying policy reforms; and (iv) effective
            utilization of available funds from other donors which were
            used to help design and implement economic reforms. Overall,
            IDA's experience with the ERC has been positive. The
            following observations emerge from the ERC's
            implementation record and outcome: (i) Strong Government
            Commitment. A sine qua non for success in the design and
            implementation of an emergency financing program is strong
            and sustained Government commitment to the policy reform
            package, as well as dynamic leadership and full ownership of
            the program by the Government. (ii) Up-front
            Conditionalities and Single Tranche Disbursement. As a
            short-term financing instrument, the ERC was well designed
            to respond on time to the immediate constraints faced by
            Mali after the devaluation. (iii) Retroactive Financing. In
            light of the urgent and extraordinary nature of the ERC, the
            Bank decided on an exceptional basis to extend the period of
            retroactive financing to August 2, 1993, about nine months
            prior to credit effectiveness, in lieu of the normal four
            months guidelines.  This decision led to faster disbursement
            arrangements and facilitated quick and easy availability of
            the credit proceeds.

abstracts.cdata!:
The African member countries of the
            Franc zone decided to devalue their currency, the CFA franc,
            effective January 12, 1994. The Economic Recovery Credit
            Project will support the post-devaluation reform program as
            outlined in the government's Statement of Economic and
            Social Policy whose main objectives are private sector led
            growth and the alleviation of poverty. The Malian government
            has already taken a series of key macroeconomic and
            structural measures to regain and consolidate
            competitiveness. The credit is designed to support the
            implementation of these measures in 1994. The major measures
            are: (a) the devaluation of the CFA franc from 50 CFAF to
            100 CFAF/1 FF; (b) increase in the producer price of prime
            quality cotton by at least 35%; (c) a program of social
            measures to attenuate the effects of the devaluation on
            vulnerable groups; (d) prudent demand management policies to
            reduce absorption by the public sector and limit wage
            increases; (e) reduction and simplification of tariffs and
            domestic taxation; and (f) protection of social sector expenditures.
